title: Thursday, 27th October, 2016

BE

accounts filed for the company’s Luxembourg-based parent show revenues for the year to May 2016 fell 4.8 per cent to $900.2m, from $945.8m in 2014.

The discrepancy is because of the decision by Misys to change its accounts from US dollars to euros as part of the IPO on the London market. It converted its 2016 revenues to stand at €811m, with the effect of significantly improving its growth rate.

BE

It is the second time that the Misys accounts have switched currency in four years. Vista switched its reporting from pounds to dollars in 2012.

11:11 am
BE

Have Berenberg to summarise.

BE

The first estimate of Q3 GDP showed that the economy expanded by 0.5% qoq – at a faster rate than our own above consensus call of 0.4% qoq. The expansion was driven by broad growth across the consumer-driven services sector (0.8%) while the industrial (-0.4%) and construction (-1.4%) sectors contracted. Although the economy slowed compared to the above-trend growth rate in Q2 (0.7% qoq), the economy has weathered the initial-Brexit shock much better than was initially expected immediately after the referendum. Today’s data suits our above consensus call for 2017 GDP growth of 1.5% versus the Bloomberg consensus of 0.8%.

The first estimate of GDP gives a limited picture of the underlying economy - covering GDP only on an industry basis. The second estimate - published in the coming weeks - will provide a detailed breakdown of consumption, government spending, investment and trade for the quarter. It will offer a better look at how the different components of the economy responded to the surprise Brexit-vote. It is likely to show that consumption continued to expand at a healthy pace, that business investment contracted amid the heightened uncertainty, and that the trade-balance improved a little as the sterling depreciation over the course of 2016 started have a positive effect. On a trade-weighted basis sterling is currently down 21% compared to November 2015.

BE

The resilient post-referendum performance does not, however, say anything about the UK’s ability to perform outside of the EU. After all, Brexit hasn’t happened yet. The good quarter of growth merely reflects the momentum heading into the vote and the healthy underlying fundamentals after some three years of good growth. Today’s data does not alter our long-term view that Brexit will lower UK trend growth, to around 1.8% from 2.2% per year, via less trade, migration and investment with its major market, the EU.

11:12 am
BE

[INSERT "BREXIT HASN'T HAPPENED YET" KLAXON HERE]

BE

Medium-term outlook
Over the medium-term, Brexit uncertainty will continue to weigh on growth prospects, driven by nervous businesses pausing investments and a slowdown in consumption growth as the higher inflation erodes real incomes. The weaker sterling will provide a modest tail-wind to exports while weakening import demand – leading to an improvement in the trade balance. We forecast below trend growth of 1.5% in 2017 and 2018 with risks tilted to the downside if the heightened risk of a hard Brexit begins to further weigh on confidence.

On a sector basis, we anticipate a slowdown in services sector growth as real incomes are squeezed. But household fundamentals will remain in ok shape. Employment is likely to remain at a high level. Household financing conditions are likely to remain favourable. The outlook for the industrial sector is mixed. While the weaker sterling should boost foreign demand, offsetting some of the weakness in domestic demand, higher costs for dollar priced inputs and energy will squeeze margins for some firms. Private construction is likely to contract as firms and households delay spending on long-lived assets. We expect Chancellor Hammond to announce an increase in infrastructure spending at the Autumn Statement (November 23). This should lead to a rise in public construction over the medium-term.

BE

Bank of England outlook
Despite recent comments from Governor Carney on the ‘limits’ to how much BoE officials can tolerate an overshoot of inflation above the 2% target, the probability of the BoE tightening policy in response to the falling sterling is very low. As long as the sterling selling is orderly, we see no major reason for the BoE to step in.

The weaker sterling reduces household real incomes. Interest rate hikes on top of that would further damage the domestic economy. The better than expected near-term performance is likely to keep the Bank of England on hold for now. However, if the economy weakened over the coming quarters, we would expect the BoE to ease monetary policy again and look through the temporarily higher inflation.

BE

.................. Meanwhile, relatedly, I note Deutsche having existential doubts about its EU bear call.

BE

One of our key calls for the Euro area for next year is our below consensus
GDP forecast for 2017 (DBe: 1.1% vs. Bloomberg Consensus 1.3%).
However, this week’s sentiment data for the Euro area strongly surprised
to the upside. Our DB SIREN surprise index rose to the highest level in 34
months pointing to near-term upside risks to our forecasts. We think that it
is too early to judge the better sentiment data as a reliable signal of a
sustained pick-up in demand, though.
 There are technical arguments that suggest the improvement is overstated:
The upside surprise was strongly tilted towards Germany and monthly
volatility might play a role. In addition, the recovery from the post-Brexit
plunge in sentiment might have been amplified by seasonality, suggesting
payback in November. Arguably, this applies to a lesser extent to the PMI
data, though.

BE

 The surprise in the manufacturing PMI could signal an improvement in
global demand. However, there are several arguments questioning the
sustainability of this development, e.g. supportive capital inflows to EMs
could proof temporary and the surge in the German and EMU new export
orders look “too strong” relative to global developments.
 Moreover, the recovery faces several headwinds in 2017: Political
uncertainty is set to remain high and will weigh on demand and especially
on investment. Increasing oil prices will continue to weigh on real incomes
and consumption. The fiscal impulse is set to weaken. A credit impulse
consistent with consensus GDP forecasts requires accelerating loan flows.
However, credit flows continued to slow in September.

11:18 am
BE

Nevertheless, a stronger end to 2016 could strengthen the hand of the
more hawkish ECB Council members. Our baseline expectation is the ECB
extends QE 9-12 months in December. More robust activity data into year-
end suggests the risk to our ECB call is a shorter extension of QE.

BE

That's post ... Praet, was it ... talking yesterday about the ECB preserving a "very substantial" monetary accommodation.

lifting potential GDP growth is not something that the central bank can do. However, it can foster favourable financing conditions to help governments embark on painful but necessary structural reforms. One of the main risks going forward is that governments will likely miss the window of opportunity provided by the ECB. While fundamentals have not improved sufficiently noticeably for the ECB to stop its purchase programme, we do not think that QE will last beyond Sep-18. We still anticipate the first refi rate hike around Dec-19.

11:24 am
BE

Operational and strategy review ongoing: Amec Foster Wheeler continues to make progress on improving its organisational structure. From 1st January the company will change its existing geographical reporting structure to four market-based business lines: Oil & Gas, Power, Mining and Environment & Infrastructure (E&I). A new "Exco" will be created with ten direct reports to the CEO, the majority of whom will be in new roles. The new structure is designed to be customer-focused and improve the consistency and cost-efficiency. The detailed review of the business has identified multiple long-term opportunities in traditional areas such as offshore greenfield oil & gas and mineable oil sands, however, more work is still required to develop detailed plans these.
To date Amec Foster Wheeler has identified around 650 surplus roles, surplus offices and is accelerating plans to outsource back office functions to low cost locations. The combined impact of proposed reduction in overheads means an additional £100m is expected to be permanently taken out of the cost base. These savings will have some impact on 2017 trading results, achieving their full run rate by 2019.
£100m disposals agreed: Agreements in principle have been reached for three assets held for sale, with combined proceeds expected before the year end of around £100m. The company is now in talks to sell the core boiler business and the rest of GPG to separate buyers. It believes this is its best option to achieve an acceptable level of proceeds. The company continues to target £500m of disposals by June 2017.

BE

Trading update and 2017 expectations: Including the £100m of disposal proceeds, and updating for recent Sterling weakness and further restructuring charges, forecast year-end net debt is now £1.1bn, up from £1bn. In the nine months to the end of September 2016, revenue was at £4,110m, 3% lower on a like-for-like basis year on year. The order book stood at £6.1bn, compared to £6.2bn at the half year. Amec Foster Wheeler’s expectations for 2016 are unchanged. In 2017, the oil & gas business is expected to continue to decline and solar activity is expected to reduce significantly from the record levels seen in 2016. This is expected to be offset by continued growth from E&I, a better performance from Mining and a significant contribution from cost savings.

PM

The new structure is designed to be customer-focused? Seriously?

11:26 am
BE

It's a new CEO trying to polish a ........ well, you know ..............

BE

Barclays incoming:

BE

The arrival of AMFW's new CEO, Jon Lewis, earlier this year came with a wave of
optimism. In our opinion he promised to deliver, delever and expose the company to
higher growth areas. There was little doubt he viewed the company structure as
sub-optimal, and he promised a new vision by mid-November. With this update, it is
clear that the task in hand is greater than expected. The underlying business
remains tough, with currency moves helping to mask P&L headwinds. Incremental
cost savings are now enumerated at GB£100mn, which should be seen as a positive,
as should a commitment to the GB£500mn disposal programme. However, the
savings will come at a material cost, the old Amec rule of thumb of "spending a
pound to save a pound" likely to be surpassed. Hence, with currency increasing
absolute GB£ debt, the company appears not to rule out any form of capital
structure, again creating the spectre of a potential capital exercise, or indeed rule
the dividend as sacrosanct. As such, despite positive moves on the savings front, the
shape of the underlying business, the magnitude of the CEO’s task in hand and the
overhang on the balance sheet, are likely to mean that the update has negative
implications following a 22% outperformance (vs. BEUOILS Index) since February.

11:27 am
BE

The positives – The company is trading in-line for 2016F and 2017F. However, 2016F is
benefiting from a meaningful FX tailwind, while 2017F includes some of the additional
GB£100mn of costs savings that have now been targeted and are beginning to be
delivered. In addition, the first GB£100mn of disposals are due this year and a
restructuring is ongoing within GPG to shape that up for sale within the previous write-
down. The commitment to GB£500mn of sales by mid-2017F remains intact.

BE

The negatives – The new CEO came, in our opinion, with a message that he will deliver.
Missing his first target, a full plan by mid-November, therefore is not the best possible
start. However, the challenges he faces and therefore the restructuring appear more
widespread than we had envisaged as the company strives for an optimal
configuration. Hence, both the structure to be announced in March 2017, and the
funding required to put it in place are unidentifiable at this juncture, the company
having not yet concluded its thinking on the right mix of investment and funding
options, leaving the door open for all capital exercises.

BE

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 801.00, no change, High: 807.50, Low: 796.00, Volume: 1.19m
11:35 am
BE

But back to BT specifically.

BE

And let me share some of a very bearish take from Saeed Baradar at Louis Capital.....

PM

Please do

11:36 am
BE

.... and not solely because I agree with it.

BE

The current significant investment in content is intended to protect the “premium” charged by BT on its broadband products (16%-52% premium vs Vodafone) by using BT TV and Sports as a retention tool. However it is important to look at the financials in a bit more detail to determine whether the returns justify the investment?

BE

BT agreed to pay £897m in the previous auction for exclusive access to European Champions League/Europa League in a 3 year deal and £960m for 3 years access to 42 matches per season in the English Premier League (up from previous £738m for 38 matches). That makes for a total payout of £1,857m for football alone. Bear in mind there is WTA (tennis) etc. but lets keep it simple at the beginning.

11:36 am
BE

According to BT’s own KPI produced at the time of the Q1 16 results (quarter ending 30 June 2016) BT had a total retail broadband base of 9,117,000 customers (includes 951k EE broadband lines transferred from Wholesale to retail following EE’s acquisition) and 1,620,000 TV customers (+59k in Q1 - another 63k added in Q2) implying a penetration rate of 17.8% (cf. 15.4% penetration in Q1-15). Tabulating these results to work out the break-even point

BE

So we get an extraordinary £31.80/month breakeven point for sports subscribers.

BE

11:38 am
BE

The argument that the break-even point of £31.8/m will decline in time as more subscribers join BT TV’s platform is absolutely valid but how much will the cost of acquiring the sports right inflate by? In the last EPL auction BT had to pay a premium of 30% over the price they had paid 3 years earlier. The European Championship/Europa league auctions are coming up and all indications are that the next EPL auctions are likely to increase significantly in value. That leaves us with two conclusions:

BT has to continue to charge premium prices for its broadband service vis-à-vis Vodafone and others operators in order to underwrite its content (TV) costs. However with Vodafone now undercutting their broadband cost as they do not need to subsidize their mobile customers, BT has no option but to reduce prices or face losing customers once the contract terms end. In either case it will be difficult to see a longer term winning scenario or
BT refuses to renew or bid for any further football rights. In such a scenario BT will be back to square one, i.e. where it was before the launch of BT Sport and therefore will face the potential loss of its broadband customers especially at a time when other operators such as Virgin Media have upgraded the reach and the quality of their network. No winning scenario here either.

BE

Do ping Mr Baradar on your Bloomberg for the full argument.

BE

For a more conventional take on the figures, here's Deutsche.

11:39 am
BE

Q2 results, the first under new CFO Simon Lowth are ahead and KPIs are
healthy but there is no change to guidance and the Co. is flagging increased
investment in H2. Any strength is an opportunity for investors to reduce
holdings ahead of potentially weaker trends in H2.
BT is facing an unfortunate concatenation of issues at this time including
pension (deficit widened considerably in the quarter: £11.5bn gross vs DBe
£11.9bn vs £7.6bn at end-Jun), increased network roll-out by Virgin Media,
regulatory tightening, Sky Mobile, plus a Govt/regulator demanding better
service levels and more investment. Separately, the Co accrues an exceptional
charge for £125m due to irregularities at BT Italia.

BE

Q2 revenues of £5,921m, 2.7% above DBe (£5,895m), 2.2% above cons,
predominantly (two-thirds) due to a large equipment sale at Global Services
brought forward. KPIs are solid and evidence little impact of competitive
pressures during the quarter (76k broadband net adds vs DBe 88k; 63k TV vs
50k DBe).
EBITDA £1,888m, in line with DBe (£1,886m), 1.6 % above cons. Adjusted EPS
of 7.2p, 6.4% ahead of DBe (6.8p) /9.1% ahead of Cons (6.6p). Normalised FCF
of £894m, 29% ahead of DBe (£689m) and 39% above cons (£642m). NB:
quarterly cashflows can be volatile and the beat in Q2 is due to both lower
capex and working capital vs DBe (perhaps light on capex due to the
Emergency Services Network deployment delay). Net debt: £9.6bn vs DBe
£9.4bn (consensus £9.8bn).
Guidance for FY 17 unchanged: £7.9bn EBITDA (DBe/Cons £7.9bn); FCF £3.1-
3.2bn compares with Dbe/cons £3.2bn. We do not expect consensus
expectations to change post today’s results print.

BE

Fidessa reported an in-line qualitative trading update this morning. Management reiterated their FY16 constant currency growth is running at similar levels to 1H16 (+4%) with some FX tailwinds if the Sterling remains at its current levels (63% of revenues outside Europe). We look for FY16E Revenues of £324.6m (+10% YoY; Consensus £321.5m) and adj. PBTA of £44.9m (+12.8% YoY; Consensus £45.5m).

BE

Overall, the group remains well positioned to benefit from regulatory changes. Although there is uncertainty following the Brexit vote, the group is not expecting any impact on the regulatory environment and expects MiFID II to be introduced as planned across Europe and the UK. The group is also making continued progress in its multi-asset initiatives and continues to explore the possibility of extending its asset class coverage (fixed income).

11:49 am

The shares have had a strong performance so far in 2016 (+15% YTD) and are now trading on a CY17 ex-cash PE of 22.4x and EV/Recurring Revenues of 3.0x - a premium to historic multiples and the UK SMID Tech peers. Whilst we acknowledge Fidessa's strong franchise, we struggle with its premium valuation and remain Neutral.

BE

This was solid but in-line trading update with management reiterating their constant currency guidance for FY16 with some FX tailwinds. We would expect consensus to remain unchanged at this stage.

BE

Organic growth of +2.4% is
performing roughly in line with MSe of 3% in the quarter and H216e growth of
+2.8%. Management state that whilst the Facility business continues to show
“good momentum” the Hospitality business is impacted by legacy UK flat linen
operations. Operational instability in the peak summer months has resulted in a
higher cost to serve in both the hospitality and workwear businesses. As a result
adjusted operating profit for 2016e is expected to be £160m vs. MSe of £169m
and consensus of £170m (company complied), with the £10m downgrade
expected to flow into 2017e where current consensus expectations is £181m and
MSe of £182m. According to management this does not relate to any external
factors such as Brexit or the living wage, this is a cost issue relating to a lack of
investment into platforms, which the current strategy seeks to address.

BE

And RBC.

BE

VIEW: We believe the issues partly reflect under-investment in the business over the last few years, but this is clearly not a great start for the relatively new CEO’s new strategy. We would expect the stock to get hit hard, given its perceived defensiveness and 17x 17E PE valuation. This does not appear to be a market issue and hence we remain positive on Johnson Service Group, which may well benefit from Berendsen’s customer service issues and trades at a material discount (17E PE 13.5x)

(This is David dialing in from Mumbai -- what a service!)

DK

A statement from Tata Sons
Mumbai, October 27, 2016: It is a matter of deep regret that a communication marked confidential to Tata Sons board members has been made public in an unseemly and undignified manner. The correspondence makes unsubstantiated claims and malicious allegations, casting aspersions on the Tata group, the Tata Sons board and several Tata companies and some respected individuals. These will be responded to in an appropriate manner.
Mr. Cyrus Mistry, the former Chairman of Tata Sons, has been on the Board of the Company since 2006. He was appointed Deputy Chairman in November, 2011, and formally appointed Chairman of Tata Sons on December 28, 2012. He would be fully familiar with the culture, ethos, governance structure, financial and operational imperatives of the Tata Group as well as various group companies. As the Executive Chairman, he was fully empowered to lead the group and its companies. It is unfortunate that it is only on his removal that allegations and misrepresentation of facts are being made about business decisions that the former Chairman was party to for over a decade in different capacities. The record, as and when made public, will prove things to the contrary.
Efforts are now being made to level accusations against individuals and company boards for ignoring corporate governance norms that were supposedly upheld by the former Chairman while in office. The Tata Sons board gives its Chairman complete autonomy to manage opportunities and challenges. However, the tenure of the former Chairman was marked by repeated departures from the culture and ethos of the group.

PM

Back story here being that Cyrus has tabled all sorts of juicy allegations about Tata

12:08 pm
DK

The Board of Directors of Tata Sons is composed of several eminent personalities from all walks of life. This is not a group of people who one would expect to act without exercising proper judgement in the best interests of the entities they sit on the boards of. It is unfortunate that Mr. Mistry had overwhelmingly lost the confidence of the Members of the Board of Directors for a combination of several factors. The Directors of the Tata Sons board had repeatedly raised queries and concerns on certain business issues, and Trustees of the Tata Trusts were increasingly getting concerned with the growing trust deficit with Mr. Mistry, but these were not being addressed. The Tata Sons board, in its collective wisdom, took the decision to replace its Chairman in the manner undertaken.
The strength of the Group is not just confined to its value system and ethics in the Board room but to a very large extent by the adherence to the values by its 600,000 plus employees whose spirit and cooperation has built the Group to where it is today. It is unforgivable that Mr. Mistry has attempted to besmirch the image of the Group in the eyes of the employees.

DK

It will be beneath the dignity of Tata Sons to engage in a public spat with regard to the several unfounded allegations appearing in his leaked confidential statement. These allegations are not based on facts or the true state of affairs. It is convenient to put selective information in the public domain to defend one's point of view. There is a multitude of records to show that the allegations made by Mr. Cyrus Mistry are unwarranted and these records will be duly disclosed before appropriate forums, if and when necessary, sufficiently justifying the decision made by responsible Boards of Directors, of Tata Sons and its Group companies.
The Interim Chairman in his first interaction with senior leaders has stressed to them the need to continue on focusing on building great businesses while emphasising on delivering strong shareholder returns. Board members of Tata Sons have in the past stressed on the need to be more decisively focused on bringing down debt, sharpening focus on both the portfolio and capital efficiency.
The Tata Group is proud of its rich legacy of contributing to the growth of the nation. During a long history, it has faced many challenges and the employees of this group have worked hard to create great companies, and deliver shareholder value. The Tata way is to not run away from problems, or constantly complain about them, but firmly deal with them and build a better tomorrow.
